Title: N/A

reviewText: I didn’t watch the original ‘Rio’ until earlier this year, and the only reason I did that was because my kids really wanted to see ‘Rio 2’ and I refuse to see a sequel without first seeing the original (or something like that).  I don’t know.  ‘Rio’ was playing on the Disney Channel or something like that and so I decided to give it a go despite not being interested in seeing it at all.So, I rather hated the original.  It’s not that the film is bad, it’s just so dull.  How can something so bright and cheery and colorful be so unexciting?Sadly, I had the same question while watching ‘Rio 2’.For a film that has so much going on, so many different characters, so many side plots, so many voices and, like I mentioned, so many colors, there is something so incredibly mundane and uninteresting about ‘Rio 2’ that it winds up being a complete bore of a film.  I know that this is not the consensus (or is it?) but I can’t help but be completely bewildered by all the praise that this film, and the original, received from my friends and family.You liked this?I can’t say that ‘Rio 2’ is bad.  It’s not.  Like I said, the original ‘Rio’ wasn’t a bad film either, but both films threatened to put me to sleep, and while ‘Rio 2’ has that one segment that could be considered my favorite scene in film this year (so far, obviously), it also proves to be an even more ridiculously mediocre film than the original.I have so many stupid qualms about this film.  Like, why is it simply called ‘Rio 2’?  The film doesn’t take place in Rio at all, outside of like three scenes in the beginning.  Why couldn’t they have called this ‘Rio: Rock the Amazon’ or something equally ridiculous?  Second, why does every film (cartoon, whatever) involving animals have to be reduced to ‘save the environment’ types of heavy handed politics?  I’m all for preserving Mother Nature, but they don’t have to make everything a political/environmental statement.  The cliché ridden plot made this feel like an animated version of ‘Meet the Parents’ for a while, and Jesse Eisenberg (and even my beloved Anne Hathaway) just don’t have the vocal abilities to carry an animated film.  Eisenberg sounds out of place and Hathaway sounds so bland (also, why isn’t she ever singing?).ZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZ.But thank Jesus that Jermaine Clement returned as Nigel.  Even in the original, Nigel proved to be this breath of fresh air, but here he is even more hilariously awesome.  Teamed up with a poison tree frog, Nigel is the comedic center point this film needed, but sadly whenever he is off the screen the film is a giant pile of wasted time.  Gabi is an inspired addition to the film (a frog in love with a bird) and her musical moment (the hilarious ‘Poisonous Love’) is the single best scene in the film and quite possibly the funniest musical moment in any film I’ve ever seen.I just wish it had been part of a better film.This is a harmless film, and the loud annoying music does make the kids happy, but this is such a bore.  I’m kind of baffled that the kids are remotely interested in this movie, but then again most kids have ADD and are drawn to loud, shiny things, no matter how pointless they are.
summary: It all falls flat in the Amazon…
Title: N/A

reviewText: Blu and Jewel are settling down to married life and have three lovely children.  However Jewel feels her family is a little too used to civilization, when a chance discovery by their human friends Linda and her husband may reveal there are more Blue Spix Macaws deep in the Amazon. It is a family road trip to see if they can help in locating more of their species, taking along Rafael and his two sidekicks (who are looking for new talent for the upcoming Carnival season - or else Raphael's wife will be the headliner).  However things will be dangerous as Nigel the evil cockatoo is hunting them with the help of his sidekick anteater and poisonous treefrog girlfriend and a greedy human who has made money with illegal lumber operations who does not want the birds to be located.  Does this one time city bird and his family have what it takes to thirve in the jungle, and when they do find them can he survive the one thing scarier than flying - his father in law?Overall this movie has the same feel as the first one.  new songs, new characters, and new locations come to life as you follow the Blu family in their quest to find more of their kind.  This is why Rio is one of the better Dreamworks shows up there with Shrek, Kung Fu Panda, and of course how to Train your dragon.  Watch it in the theaters and wait for this to come out in the near future.

reviewText: Animated sequels often suffer from the same amount of scrutiny and criticism as the rest of big Hollywood sequels.  It can easily become a daunting task to not only create a successful animated film (which is no guarantee these days), but to also make the sequel as entertaining as the original.  Recent and extremely lackluster sequels, such as Cars 2, Shrek the Third, and basically any of the Ice Age sequels have all proved that animated sequels desire a great deal more attention than they are typically given.  Still, that’s not to say all animated sequels are sub-par, especially when additions like Toy Story 2, Monsters University, and Despicable Me 2 each managed to find success in the shadow of terrific first outings.  But, let’s be honest here – Rio was an average animated feature, and it was certainly no Toy Story, meaning the fact that it was given a sequel screams that there’s currently a serious lack of originality from film studios.Directed by Carlos Saldanha (Rio, Ice Age), Rio 2 once again stars the voice of Jesse Eisenberg as Blu, the accident-prone house bird from Minnesota.  In the first film, Blu found the love of his life, Jewel (Anne Hathaway), and now they have a family of their own.  They currently live in Rio with Linda (Leslie Mann) and Tulio (Rodrigo Santoro), who have made their way to the Amazon – and happen to stumble upon the possibility of a new flock of Spix Macaws (they are supposedly nearly extinct).  Blu and Jewel witness the discovery on the news and the family heads to the Amazon to help with the search.After arriving in the Amazon, Blu and the family, accompanied by Rafael the Toucan (George Lopez), Pedro the Cardinal (will.i.am), and Nico the Yellow Canary (Jamie Foxx), quickly discovers that Jewel’s father, Eduardo (Andy Garcia), is alive and well.  He is the leader of a massive tribe of Spix Macaws, which includes one of Jewels’ childhood friends, Roberto (Bruno Mars) – both of whom find Blu’s domesticated habits to be problematic.  And, at the same time, Nigel (Jermaine Clement), the vengeful Cockatoo, and his cohorts, which includes a poisonous frog, Gabi (Kristin Chenoweth), follow Blu to the Amazon with the intent to put an end to him.For an animated sequel, there is a whole lot going on over the course of the film – yet the strangest thing about all of it is the fact that little of the plot-based elements ever fully establishes the sequel with a clear-cut purpose.  One minute this story is about whether or not more Spix Macaws exist, then there’s an abrupt and needless love triangle, followed by the close-minded father dictating all the infallible survival rules of the rain forest.  Plus, you have the villain from the previous film, Nigel, seeking revenge, not to mention humans knocking down trees and attempting to kill the Amazon’s inhabitants.  On top of all of that, there’s supporting cast members conducting talent show interviews, a flock of rival birds creating a turf war, and Linda and Tulio wondering about with a video recorder documenting the couple’s ridiculous adventure.  I don’t know about you, but do you think there are enough plotlines stuffed into a roughly 90-minute movie?Regardless of the plot issues, the cast is by far the bright spot of the film.  Jesse Eisenberg is a tremendous actor that channels Blu’s scatter-brained, awkward demeanor perfectly.  Eisenberg simply amplifies every role that he’s involved in, and at no point will viewers be disappointed by his acting or voice work (a notion that should be imbedded into the minds of anyone that believes he won’t make an excellent Lex Luthor in the Man of Steel sequel).  He also has wonderful chemistry with the absurdly talented Anne Hathaway, who portrays animated bride.  Her role appears to be slightly reduced from the first film, which is no surprise with the massive amount of characters incorporated into this sequel.  Never the less, Hathaway has a marvelous voice (and if you haven’t fully heard it, you should check out Les Misérables), but it would have been nice had she been given more of a substantial singing role.Speaking of singing, Kristin Chenoweth steals the show as a love-struck, poisonous frog.  She is given not only a charming character, but the major singing role, too.  Again, if you haven’t heard her voice in the past, you should make an attempt to purchase one of her outstanding studio albums.  Over the course of the film, her character pines for the villainous Nigel, thus creating several of the film’s most humorous moments.  The downsize to Chenoweth’s role is that the rest of the supporting cast suffers, especially Tracy Morgan as the slobbering dog, Luiz – who is only in the film’s opening moments.  Oddly enough, Morgan’s witty distinctiveness was one of the bright spots of Rio, so his reduced (cameo) role comes as an unfortunate disappointment.Naturally, a movie titled Rio should probably at least take place in Rio, yet that’s not the case here.  The sentiment of the location is fully intact, but like Madagascar, the plot takes the characters to a new, grander location.  Naturally, this new direction broadens the landscape of the film’s universe, all while establishing new characters and so on and so forth.  Still, if Rio 2 is ultimately a success (and it’s hard to imagine it wouldn’t be), Rio 3 will likely need to create a reason for the characters to migrate back to Rio.  Otherwise, Rio 3 could simply change its name to The Jungle Book (never mind, that’s already taken).Overall, Rio 2 is another beautifully colorful animated feature.  Still, it’s not an exceptional sequel, nor is it disappointing, either.  The majority of the characters from the first film are back for more fun, albeit with reduced roles.  Clearly, the plot of Rio is jumbled, but it’s hard to imagine the kids voicing any kind of complaint.  Adults will be entertained, too, but you’ll notice a few oddities in the movie, including the art of “war” being the equivalent of a soccer match, and the blatant message that humans are a danger to the survival of the Amazon.  The issue of protecting the rainforests (referred to as “tree hugging” in the movie) serves a vitally important role in the climax of the movie.  Regardless of the thematic messages and the fact that the film’s plot is too clustered and overly ambitious, Rio 2 will is still recommended as a safe choice for a family outing.GRADE:  CFNDNreview.com
summary: 'Rio 2' features terrific cast, beautiful colors, but clustered plot

reviewText: What can I say? This colorful, tuneful, G-rated romp made the children in Saturday morning's screening audience happy; what more do we want? I enjoyed watching a flock of endangered blue macaws do "The Wave" to show their applause during a soccer match and their appreciation for a musical number. Their aerial ballet had echoes of both Esther Williams and Busby Berkeley: You know, those dazzling kaleidoscopic effects.Our hero, Blu, lives with his lovely mate Jewel and their three offspring in Rio de Janeiro. She would like to visit her old jungle haunts and maybe reconnect with her family; on the other hand, he is city born and bred but adores her, so agrees to a little vacation trip ("A happy wife is a happy life"). Their adventure begins.We follow:* Blu (Jesse Eisenberg) raised to be a "Companion" for environmentalist Linda, he has now mastered flight but finds he must contend with Jewel's macho father out in the wild. His fanny pack contains a GPS unit ("Recalculating...") and an electric toothbrush.* Jewel (Anne Hathaway) adores her little family but is concerned for The Flock as deforestation encroaches on their territory.*  Linda (Leslie Mann) is as sweetly earnest as ever, this environmentalist is now very concerned about the deforestation of the Amazon rain forest.* Tulio (Rodrigo Santoro) is her clumsy ornithologist who goes on treks with her because he is still looking for a (possibly extinct) flock of blue macaws.* Roberto (Bruno Mars) seems to be a contender for Jewel's affections.* Big Boss (Miguel Ferrer) runs that evil logging operation with massive bulldozers, earth movers and tree-cutting equipment.* Nico (Jamie Foxx) provides the vocals for "Crazy Love."* Aunt Mimi (Rita Moreno) provides a bit of comic relief that the parents will appreciate.* Nigel (Jemaine Clement) is a down-on-his luck fellow forced to work as a fortune teller's assistant in a street show. He wears a Pagliacci-type costume to cover the bald spot from his male pattern feather loss.* Gabi (Kristen Chenoweth) is a poisonous dart tree frog who sings everything from showtunes to opera. She is desperately in love with Nigel.The villain this time would be the logging companies that are stripping the trees from the Amazon jungle. The movie makes it very clear that even though the birds have some natural enemies, their worst long-term problem is loss of habitat.The most impressive things to me, are the editing and the artwork: The editing is to the beat of a Samba-flavored soundtrack; the artwork includes a bird's-eye view of Rio's favelas (shantytowns) which cling to the mountain sides. BTW, Sergio Mendez is the music producer working with Brazilian director Carlos Saldanha ("Ice Age" and "Rio").
summary: A Happy Wife is a Happy Life

reviewerName: Lorenzo M. in the Hollywood CA Area "Movie Wa...
reviewText: As far as sequels go, “Rio 2” is an average attempt at revitalizing characters that usually always better in their original film. Like in this case, Blue Sky productions (the people who brought you the “Ice Age” films) and director Carlos Saldanha (Rio, Robots) tried to capture the essence of the first one and did something a little different – made it more choppy and added a ot more musical numbers. (Maybe it was done in an attempt to keep up with Disney and their ‘musical’ market in animation.)It seems the songs that were added in this film were the only reason for all the animation vignettes we see in the movie. As vignettes of musical pieces (the songs/musical numbers) are impressive with great visuals and colors and coordination, however the songs – even though they are actually quite good - as far as advancing the story or adding to the individual characters or their levels of interest, they didn’t do much of that at all.With four writers Jenny, Bicks, Carlos Saldanha, Yoni Brenner and Carlos Kotkin, it seems that they were each working on a specific story line but the film couldn’t decide if it was a family piece, adventure piece or an environmental piece. There was really no through line for the story in it.It’s basically supposed to be a story about our favorite family of Blue Cockatoos going on a vacation only to discover they are not the only “Blues” out there in existence. It’s a family reunion of the wife’s linage that occurs first as well as the issue of the destruction of the rain forest. There are fellow “Reds” (Red Cockatoos) who are birds that literally pop in one scene and act as the mortal enemies of the Blue’s and then the next time you see them, they are fighting with them wind’n’wing (arm’n’arm).The funniest performances came from Kristin Chenoweth (Pushing Daisies, Glee) as the forest frog Gabi and Jermaine Clement (Men In Black II, Flight Of the Conchords) as Nigel who one things is deadly poisonous and the other a world-class actor. These two partners in crime (who are the villains of the film) have some of the best bits and even share a wonderful song that showcases their evilness from beginning to the end.Of course Jesse Eisenberg (The Social Network, Now You See Me) is back as Blu (dad) and Anne Hathaway (Les Miserables, Alice In Wonderland) is back as Jewel (mom). And their three kids that they have are now more than a handful for them as parents. (Or ‘Featherful’?)Other celebrity appearances as voices included Rita Moreno, Will I Am, Jamie Foxx, Tracy Morgan, Bruno Mars, Miguel Ferrer, George Lopez and Andy Garcia. It has its heartfelt moments where the kids learn about family and even the ending has a nice heroic twist for everyone to enjoy, but the film still felt a little long and not connected overall.To me, “Rio” was a much more fun, funny and had a much more well-rounded story and more meaning as a film. “Rio 2” does have some very funny moments and definitely some great music in it but I’d wait for the video or Netflix on this one. Tell them Lorenzo at [...]TheGeekAuthority told you so!
summary: “Rio 2” Is High Flying Birds, But Doesn’t Pack A Lot Of Punch”

reviewText: It isn't often that a sequel can live up to the original, but Rio 2 manages to pull it off. In this movie, Blue and Jewel take a family trip to the Amazon where they are reunited with Jewel's father who they believed was killed in a forest fire.  They also discover they aren't the last of their species as they had feared. There is a whole flock living deep in the Amazon, but the threat of deforestation makes their extinction a real possibility.  Blue is anxious to get home, especially since Jewel's father gives him a hard time about being a pet, but Jewel is drawn to the wild that was originally her home.  The two of them have to decide what's best their family--stay in the wild or return to their owners and the safety of their home in Rio.Rio 2 is an adorable movie with tons of great songs and fun characters. My kids enjoyed the rivalry with the red macaws and the soccer game that ensued. It was also fun to see Nigel return along with his love-struck frog sidekick. There was plenty of action and lots of bright colors. My family enjoyed this movie just as much as the original and my kids were thrilled that there favorite birds were back in flight.

reviewText: So we took my daughter to the movies for her birthday.  Rio 2 was the only "kid" movie playing at the theater. I loved the first movie but was rather disappointed in the second. I wanted to see more of the original cast especially Tulio because his character is very funny. However I really enjoyed the poisonous frog. Kristin Chenoweth (Tinkerbell, RV, You Again ect) does her voice and is one of my favorite Actresses.Filled with tons of songs a slow spuratic story line and wasn't really funny at all. I'm not sure what I was expecting but the sequal didnt love up to it. Blue being reminded throughout the movie "happy wife happy life" made me chuckle the first time. After that it got old,  and again I just wish it had lived up to the first one.Since it was a kid movie I asked my kids (8 &5) what they thought.  My son offered no real reply other than explaining how he wanted to see Captain America (again). My daughted told me it was ok but not great kinda medium.My husband told me he chuckled once then fell asleep. He also told me he wished we had not wasted our money on seeing it in theaters.Overall Its not awful, but I'd recommend waiting till you can rent it or purchase it on dvd for the same price as 1 or 2 movie tickets.
summary: I really wanted it to be better

reviewText: This is another song filled film that my grand niece loved. Rumors that a flock of Blues might live deep in the Amazon causes Blue, Jewel, the three kids, and the usual suspects to venture there. If they can find the endangered species, they can save the rain forest from the evil logging company.Jewel unites with family and an old friend that causes some jealous feelings in Blue who was a 'pet" for the humans. reviewText: Directed by Carlos Saldanha, who did the original Rio, Rio 2 is an enjoyable sequel even though the plot tends to suffer a bit from both a certain predictability and from having so many characters that some don't get enough attention to be fully developed.  The animation, however, remains gorgeous, taking full advantage of the brilliant color palate that the Brazilian Amazon setting has to offer.The plot centers around the apparent discovery by Linda (Leslie Mann) and Tulio (Rodrigo Santoro) of what might be an entire colony of blue Spix's Macaws deep in the Amazon.  Blu (Jesse Eisenberg) and Jewel (Anne Hathaway), are back at the house in Rio with their three kids:  artistically-inclined Carla (Rachel Crow), book-smart Bia (Amanda Stenberg) and adventuresome Tiago (Pierce Gagnon). Hearing about Linda and Tulio's discovery on TV, Jewel is excited that there might be others of their kind and immediately wants the family to fly to the Amazon to join Linda and Tulio in their search.  Blu, a city-bird at heart, is more than a little reluctant, but he goes along to please Jewel, who wants their kids to experience their jungle heritage.  Complications however quickly arise on a number of fronts.  The first comes from an illegal logging operation who doesn't want Linda and Tulio's discovery to bring attention to the part of the Amazon where they're cutting trees, or worse, end up turning the area into a protected preserve.  The second comes from what happens when Blu and Jewel encounter the newly discovered macaw colony which Jewel finds is actually part of her past. Which in turn is further complicated by a rival colony of scarlet macaws vying with the blue macaws over territory. And last but far from least comes Nigel (Jermaine Clement), the villainous cockatoo from the first film who has sworn vengeance on Blu, accompanied this time by a poisonous (and quite lovesick) tree frog named Gabi (Kristin Chenoweth) and a silent and not-so-bright tamandua ant-eater named Charlie [a tip-of-the-hat to Charlie Chaplin whom he ends up mimicking at times).All of the characters from the first Rio return in Rio 2, with the addition of several new characters. This however creates a problem in that there are so many characters that several end up getting somewhat shorted in terms of on-screen character development, particularly the new ones. The film would've probably been better off it the writers had simply dropped some of the characters from the first film to make room for the new ones. As it is, their inclusion seems forced and really adds nothing to the film but sucks up screen time that could've been better used on the new characters.And in addition to the characters being shorted, the plot also gets shorted as it tries to deal with a number of different threads and ends up being rather predictable because there is no time for any complex development. As it is, the conflict between the good guys/birds and the evil illegal loggers is completely predictable, as is the conflict between the two rival macaw colonies and the conflict within Blu and Jewel's suddenly extended family.  It's not that any of this is badly done, mind you. It's all well done for what it is.  It's just that it would've been nice to have been surprised now and then.The best part of the film are the scenes with Nigel and Gabi. It often happens that the villains end up being the most interesting characters, having the best scenes, the best lines and even the best musical numbers, and this is definitely one of those times. Nigel's "I Will Survive" and Gabi's "Poisonous Love" are far and away the best songs in the film. And it really helps that for all of his villainous nature, Nigel is a hammy performer at heart, always over-acting and drawn to the limelight and playing for the crowd even in the middle of carrying out his revenge. And Gabi's hopeless crush on Nigel gives her a surprisingly sympathetic side, her poisonous skin condemning her to always having to adore Nigel from afar. And like I said, the two of them have the best lines in the movie, like this little exchange:Nigel [in stage-like proclaiming]: "The croaking cockatoo doth bellow for revenge!"[Gabi looks on adoringly]Nigel [in normal voice]: "That's Shakespeare, by the way."Gabi [gushing]: "Without your performance, it's nothing."Nigel: "Fair point."Recommended for fans of the original Rio and for the scenes where Nigel and Gabi breathe some originality and vitality- even if it is villainous - into the story.
summary: So-so plot elevated by beautiful animation and by scene-stealing villains Nigel & Gabi
